pli-tv-bi-pm:5.1: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-bi-pm:5.2: Today is the observance day, the fifteenth.
pli-tv-bi-pm:5.3: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, it should do the observance-day ceremony, it should recite the Monastic Code.
pli-tv-bi-pm:6.1: What is the preliminary duty of the Sangha?
pli-tv-bi-pm:6.2: The venerables should declare their purity.
pli-tv-bi-pm:6.3: I will recite the Monastic Code.
pli-tv-bi-pm:6.4: Everyone present should listen to it and attend carefully.
pli-tv-bi-pm:6.5: Anyone who has committed an offense should reveal it.
pli-tv-bi-pm:6.6: If you haven’t committed any offense, you should remain silent.
pli-tv-bi-pm:6.7: If you are silent, I will regard you as pure.
pli-tv-bi-pm:6.8: Just as one responds when asked individually, so too, an announcement is made three times in this kind of gathering.
pli-tv-bi-pm:6.9: If a nun remembers an offense while the announcement is being made up to the third time, but doesn’t reveal it, she is lying in full awareness.
pli-tv-bi-pm:6.10: Lying in full awareness is called an obstacle by the Buddha.
pli-tv-bi-pm:6.11: A nun who remembers an offense and is seeking purification should therefore reveal it.
pli-tv-bi-pm:6.12: When it’s revealed, she will be at ease.
pli-tv-bi-pm:7.1: Venerables, the introduction has been recited;
pli-tv-bi-pm:7.2: In regard to this I ask you, ‘Are you pure in this?’
pli-tv-bi-pm:7.3: A second time I ask, ‘Are you pure in this?’
pli-tv-bi-pm:7.4: A third time I ask, ‘Are you pure in this?’
pli-tv-bi-pm:7.5: You are pure in this and therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’
pli-tv-bi-pm:8.1: Venerables, these eight rules on expulsion come up for recitation.
pli-tv-bi-pm:9.1: If a nun, willingly has sexual intercourse, even with a male animal, she is expelled and excluded from the community.
pli-tv-bi-pm:10.1: If a nun, intending to steal, takes from an inhabited area or from the wilderness what has not been given to him—
pli-tv-bi-pm:10.2: the sort of stealing for which kings, having caught a thief, would beat, imprison, or banish her, saying, ‘You’re a bandit, you’re a fool, you’ve gone astray, you’re a thief’
pli-tv-bi-pm:10.3: —she is expelled and excluded from the community.
pli-tv-bi-pm:11.1: If a nun intentionally kills a human being or seeks an instrument of death for her or praises death or incites someone to die, saying,
pli-tv-bi-pm:11.2: ‘My friend, what’s the point of this miserable and difficult life? Death is better for you than life!’—
pli-tv-bi-pm:11.3: thinking and intending thus, if she praises death in many ways or incites someone to die
pli-tv-bi-pm:11.4: —she too is expelled and excluded from the community.
pli-tv-bi-pm:12.1: If a nun falsely claims for himself a superhuman quality, a knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, saying, ‘This I know, this I see,’
pli-tv-bi-pm:12.2: but after some time—whether she is questioned or not, but having committed the offense and seeking purification—should say: ‘Not knowing I said that I know, not seeing that I see; what I said was empty and false,’ then,
pli-tv-bi-pm:12.3: except if it is due to overestimation,
pli-tv-bi-pm:12.4: she too is expelled and excluded from the community.
pli-tv-bi-pm:13.1: If a lustful nun consents to a lustful man making physical contact with her, to touching her, to taking hold of her, to contacting her, or to squeezing her, anywhere below the collar bone but above the knees, she too is expelled and excluded from the community. The training rule on above the knees.
pli-tv-bi-pm:14.1: If a nun knows that a nun has committed an offense entailing expulsion, but she neither confronts her herself nor tells a group of nuns, and afterward—whether that nun remains or has died or has been expelled or has converted—she says, ‘Venerables, although I previously knew that this nun was like this, I thought, I will neither confront her myself nor tell a group of nuns, she too is expelled and excluded from the community. The training rule on those who conceal offenses.
pli-tv-bi-pm:15.1: If a nun takes sides with a monk who has been ejected by a unanimous Sangha—in accordance with the rule, the Monastic Law, and the Teacher’s instruction—and who is disrespectful, who has not made amends, and who has not made friends, the nuns should correct her like this:
pli-tv-bi-pm:15.2: ‘Venerable, this monk has been ejected by a unanimous Sangha in accordance with the rule, the Monastic Law, and the Teacher’s instruction. He’s disrespectful, hasn’t made amends, and hasn’t made friends. Venerable, don’t take sides with this monk.’
pli-tv-bi-pm:15.3: If that nun continues as before, the nuns should press her up to three times to make her stop.
pli-tv-bi-pm:15.4: If she then stops, all is well.
pli-tv-bi-pm:15.5: If she does not stop, she too is expelled and excluded from the community. The training rule on taking sides with one who has been ejected.
pli-tv-bi-pm:16.1: If, for the purpose of indulging in inappropriate sexual conduct, a lustful nun consents to a lustful man holding her hand and the edge of her robe, and she stands with him and chats with him and goes to an appointment with him and consents to him coming to her and enters a covered place with him and disposes her body for him for that purpose, she too is expelled and excluded from the community. The training rule having eight parts.
pli-tv-bi-pm:17.1: “Venerables, the eight rules on expulsion have been recited.
pli-tv-bi-pm:17.2: If a nun commits any one of them, she is no longer part of the community of nuns.
pli-tv-bi-pm:17.3: As before, so after: she’s expelled and excluded from the community.
pli-tv-bi-pm:17.4: In regard to this I ask you, ‘Are you pure in this?’
pli-tv-bi-pm:17.5: A second time I ask, ‘Are you pure in this?’
pli-tv-bi-pm:17.6: A third time I ask, ‘Are you pure in this?’
pli-tv-bi-pm:17.7: You are pure in this and therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’
pli-tv-bi-pm:17.8: The offenses entailing expulsion are finished.
pli-tv-bi-pm:18.1: Venerables, these seventeen rules on suspension come up for recitation.
pli-tv-bi-pm:19.1: If a nun takes legal action against a householder or a householder’s offspring or a slave or a worker or even toward a monastic or a wanderer, then that nun has committed an immediate offense entailing sending away and suspension.
pli-tv-bi-pm:20.1: If a nun, without getting permission from the king or the Sangha or a community or an association or a society, gives the full admission to a woman who she knows is a criminal and who is known as sentenced to death, then, except when it is allowable, that nun too has committed an immediate offense entailing sending away and suspension.
pli-tv-bi-pm:21.1: If a nun walks to the next inhabited area by herself or crosses a river by herself or spends the night apart by herself or lags behind her companions by herself, then that nun too has committed an immediate offense entailing sending away and suspension.
pli-tv-bi-pm:22.1: If a nun, without getting permission from the Sangha that did the legal procedure and without the consent of the group, reinstates a nun who has been ejected by a unanimous Sangha in accordance with the rule and the Monastic Law and the Teacher’s instruction, then that nun too has committed an immediate offense entailing sending away and suspension.
pli-tv-bi-pm:23.1: If a lustful nun eats fresh or cooked food after receiving it directly from a lustful man, then that nun too has committed an immediate offense entailing sending away and suspension.
pli-tv-bi-pm:24.1: If a nun says, ‘Venerable, what can this man do to you, whether he has lust or not, if you’re without? Go on, Venerable, receive it with your own hands and then eat whatever fresh or cooked food he gives you,’ then that nun too has committed an immediate offense entailing sending away and suspension.
pli-tv-bi-pm:25.1: If a nun acts as a matchmaker, conveying a man’s intention to a woman or a woman’s intention to a man, for marriage or for an affair, even if just a brief one, she commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bi-pm:26.1: If a nun who is angry and displeased groundlessly charges a nun with an offense entailing expulsion, aiming to make her leave the monastic life,
pli-tv-bi-pm:26.2: and then after some time, whether she is questioned or not, it is clear that the legal issue is groundless, and she admits to her ill will, she commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bi-pm:27.1: “If a nun who is angry and displeased, uses an unrelated legal issue as a pretext to charge a nun with an offense entailing expulsion, aiming to make her leave the monastic life,”
pli-tv-bi-pm:27.2: and then after some time, whether she is questioned or not, it is clear that the legal issue is unrelated and was used as pretext, and she admits to her ill will, she commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bi-pm:28.1: If a nun says in anger,
pli-tv-bi-pm:28.2: I renounce the Buddha, I renounce the Teaching, I renounce the Sangha, I renounce the training! The Sakyan daughters are not the only monastics. There are other monastics who have a sense of conscience, who are afraid of wrongdoing and fond of the training. I’ll practice the spiritual life with them,’
pli-tv-bi-pm:28.3: then the nuns should correct her like this:
pli-tv-bi-pm:28.4: ‘Venerable, don’t say such things in anger, I renounce the Buddha, I renounce the Teaching, I renounce the Sangha, I renounce the training! The Sakyan daughters are not the only monastics. There are other monastics who have a sense of conscience, who are afraid of wrongdoing and fond of the training. I’ll practice the spiritual life with them.’ Take delight, Venerable; the Teaching is well proclaimed. Practice the spiritual life for the complete ending of suffering.’
pli-tv-bi-pm:28.5: If that nun continues as before, the nuns should press her up to three times to make her stop.
pli-tv-bi-pm:28.6: If she then stops, all is well.
pli-tv-bi-pm:28.7: If she does not stop, then after the third announcement that nun too has committed an offense entailing sending away and suspension.
pli-tv-bi-pm:29.1: If a nun is angry because a legal issue has been decided against her, saying,
pli-tv-bi-pm:29.2: ‘The nuns are acting out of favoritism, ill will, confusion, and fear,’  then the nuns should correct her like this:
pli-tv-bi-pm:29.3: ‘Venerable, just because you’re angry that a legal issue has been decided against you, don’t say, ‘The nuns are acting out of favoritism, ill will, confusion, and fear.’ Perhaps it’s you who are acting out of favoritism, ill will, confusion, and fear.’
pli-tv-bi-pm:29.4: If that nun continues as before, the nuns should press her up to three times to make her stop.
pli-tv-bi-pm:29.5: If she then stops, all is well.
pli-tv-bi-pm:29.6: If she does not stop, then after the third announcement that nun too has committed an offense entailing sending away and suspension.
pli-tv-bi-pm:30.1: If nuns socialize, behave badly, have a bad reputation, are notorious, harass the Sangha of nuns, and hide each other’s offenses,
pli-tv-bi-pm:30.2: then the nuns should correct them like this:
pli-tv-bi-pm:30.3: ‘Sisters, you socialize, behave badly, have a bad reputation, are notorious, harass the Sangha of nuns, and hide each other’s offenses.
pli-tv-bi-pm:30.4: Be secluded, Venerables. The Sangha praises seclusion for the Sisters.’
pli-tv-bi-pm:30.5: If those nuns continues as before, the nuns should press them up to three times to make them stop.
pli-tv-bi-pm:30.6: If they then stops, all is well.
pli-tv-bi-pm:30.7: If they do not stop, then after the third announcement those nuns too have committed an offense entailing sending away and suspension.
pli-tv-bi-pm:31.2: ‘Venerables, you should socialize. Don’t live separately.
pli-tv-bi-pm:31.3: There are other nuns in the Sangha who have such behavior, reputation, and notoriety, and who harass the Sangha of nuns and hide each other’s offenses. The Sangha says nothing to them.
pli-tv-bi-pm:31.4: It’s because of disrespect, contempt, impatience, and slander, and because you are weak that the Sangha says to you, ‘Sisters, you socialize, behave badly, have a bad reputation, are notorious, harass the Sangha of nuns, and hide each other’s offenses. Be secluded, Venerables. The Sangha praises seclusion for the Sisters,
pli-tv-bi-pm:31.5: then the nuns should correct her like this:
pli-tv-bi-pm:31.7: ‘Venerables, you should socialize. Don’t live separately.
pli-tv-bi-pm:31.8: There are other nuns in the Sangha who have such behavior, reputation, and notoriety, and who harass the Sangha of nuns and hide each other’s offenses. The Sangha says nothing to them.
pli-tv-bi-pm:31.9: It’s because of disrespect, contempt, impatience, and slander, and because you are weak that the Sangha says to you, ‘Sisters, you socialize, behave badly, have a bad reputation, are notorious, harass the Sangha of nuns, and hide each other’s offenses. Be secluded, Venerables. The Sangha praises seclusion for the Sisters,
pli-tv-bi-pm:31.10: If that nun continues as before, the nuns should press her up to three times to make her stop.
pli-tv-bi-pm:31.11: If she then stops, all is well.
pli-tv-bi-pm:31.12: If she does not stop, then after the third announcement that nun too has committed an offense entailing sending away and suspension.
pli-tv-bi-pm:32.0: Suspension 14. Causing Schism in the Saṅgha
pli-tv-bi-pm:32.1: If a nun pursues schism in a united Sangha or persists in taking up a legal issue conducive to schism, the nuns should correct her like this,
pli-tv-bi-pm:32.2: ‘Venerable, don’t pursue schism in the united Sangha or persist in taking up a legal issue conducive to schism.
pli-tv-bi-pm:32.3: Stay with the Sangha, for a united Sangha—in concord, in harmony, having a joint recitation—is at ease.’
pli-tv-bi-pm:32.4: If that nun continues as before, the nuns should press her up to three times to make her stop.
pli-tv-bi-pm:32.5: If she then stops, all is well.
pli-tv-bi-pm:32.6: If she does not stop, then after the third announcement that nun too has committed an offense entailing sending away and suspension.
pli-tv-bi-pm:33.1: That nun may have one, two, or three nuns who side with her and support her, and they may say,
pli-tv-bi-pm:33.3: She speaks in accordance with the Teaching and the training.
pli-tv-bi-pm:33.4: And she speaks with our consent and approval. She knows about us and speaks for us, and we approve of this.”
pli-tv-bi-pm:33.5: then the nuns should correct those nuns like this:
pli-tv-bi-pm:33.7: this nun speaks contrary to the Teaching and the training.
pli-tv-bi-pm:33.8: And don’t consent to schism in the Sangha.
pli-tv-bi-pm:33.9: Stay with the Sangha, for a united Sangha—in concord, in harmony, having a joint recitation—is at ease.'
pli-tv-bi-pm:33.10: If those nuns continues as before, the nuns should press them up to three times to make them stop.
pli-tv-bi-pm:33.11: If they then stops, all is well.
pli-tv-bi-pm:33.12: If they do not stop, then after the third announcement those nuns too have committed an offense entailing sending away and suspension.
pli-tv-bi-pm:34.1: If a nun is difficult to correct, and she makes herself incorrigible when legitimately corrected by the nuns concerning the training rules that are recited, saying,
pli-tv-bi-pm:34.2: “Venerables, don’t say anything to me, either good or bad, and I won’t say anything to you, either good or bad.
pli-tv-bi-pm:34.4: then the nuns should correct her like this:
pli-tv-bi-pm:34.5: 'Be easy to correct, Venerable, not incorrigible.
pli-tv-bi-pm:34.6: And please give legitimate correction to the nuns, and the nuns will do the same to you.
pli-tv-bi-pm:34.7: For it’s in this way that the Buddha’s community has grown, that is, through mutual correction and mutual clearing of offenses.'
pli-tv-bi-pm:34.8: If that nun continues as before, the nuns should press her up to three times to make her stop.
pli-tv-bi-pm:34.9: If she then stops, all is well.
pli-tv-bi-pm:34.10: If she does not stop, then after the third announcement that nun too has committed an offense entailing sending away and suspension.
pli-tv-bi-pm:35.1: If a nun who lives supported by a village or town is a corrupter of families and badly behaved, and her bad behavior has been seen and heard about, and the families corrupted by her have been seen and heard about,
pli-tv-bi-pm:35.2: then the nuns should correct her like this:
pli-tv-bi-pm:35.3: 'Venerable, you’re a corrupter of families and badly behaved. Your bad behavior has been seen and heard about, and the families corrupted by you have been seen and heard about. Leave this monastery; you’ve stayed here long enough.'
pli-tv-bi-pm:35.5: 'You’re acting out of desire, ill will, confusion, and fear. Because of this sort of offense, you only banish some, but not others,'
pli-tv-bi-pm:35.6: then the nuns should correct her like this:
pli-tv-bi-pm:35.7: 'No, Venerable, the nuns are not acting out of desire, ill will, confusion, and fear.
pli-tv-bi-pm:35.8: Venerable, you’re a corrupter of families and badly behaved. Your bad behavior has been seen and heard about, and the families corrupted by you have been seen and heard about. Leave this monastery; you’ve stayed here long enough.'
pli-tv-bi-pm:35.9: If that nun continues as before, the nuns should press her up to three times to make her stop.
pli-tv-bi-pm:35.10: If she then stops, all is well.
pli-tv-bi-pm:35.11: If she does not stop, then after the third announcement that nun too has committed an offense entailing sending away and suspension.
pli-tv-bi-pm:36.1: “Venerables, the seventeen rules on suspension have been recited, nine being immediate offenses, eight after the third announcement.
pli-tv-bi-pm:36.2: If a nun commits any one of them, she is to must undertake a trial period for a half-month toward both Sanghas.
pli-tv-bi-pm:36.3: When this is completed, she is to be rehabilitated wherever there is a sangha of at least twenty nuns.
pli-tv-bi-pm:36.4: If that nun is rehabilitated by a sangha of nuns of even one less than twenty,
pli-tv-bi-pm:36.5: In regard to this I ask you, ‘Are you pure in this?’
pli-tv-bi-pm:36.6: A second time I ask, ‘Are you pure in this?’
pli-tv-bi-pm:36.7: A third time I ask, ‘Are you pure in this?’
pli-tv-bi-pm:36.8: You are pure in this and therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’
pli-tv-bi-pm:36.9: The chapter on offenses entailing suspension is finished.
pli-tv-bi-pm:37.1: Venerables, these thirty rules on relinquishment and confession come up for recitation.
pli-tv-bi-pm:38.1: If a nun collects almsbowls, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bi-pm:39.1: If a nun determines out-of-season robe-cloth as In-season’, and then distributes it, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bi-pm:40.1: If a nun swaps robes with a nun and then says, ‘Here’s your robe; give me that robe of mine. That which is yours is yours, and that which is mine is mine. Give me that, and take back what’s yours;’ and she just takes it or has it taken, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bi-pm:41.1: If a nun asks for one thing and then for something else, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bi-pm:42.1: If a nun gets one thing in exchange and then something else, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bi-pm:43.1: When a requisite belonging to the Sangha is designated for a specific purpose, if a nun exchanges it for something else, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bi-pm:44.1: When a requisite belonging to the Sangha is designated for a specific purpose and was asked for, if a nun exchanges it for something else, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bi-pm:45.1: When a collective requisite is designated for a specific purpose, if a nun exchanges it for something else, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bi-pm:46.1: When a collective requisite is designated for a specific purpose and was asked for, if a nun exchanges it for something else, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bi-pm:47.1: When a personal requisite is designated for a specific purpose and was asked for, if a nun exchanges it for something else, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bi-pm:47.2: The sub-chapter on bowls is finished
pli-tv-bi-pm:48.1: If a nun carries out an exchange to get a heavy cloak, it is to be worth at most four _kaṁsa_ coins. If she gets one in exchange that is worth more than that, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bi-pm:49.1: If a nun carries out an exchange to get a light cloak, it is to be worth at most two-and-a-half _kaṁsa_ coins. If she gets one in exchange that is worth more than that, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bi-pm:50.1: When her robe is finished and the robe season has ended, a nun should keep an extra robe for ten days at the most.
pli-tv-bi-pm:50.2: If she keeps it longer than that, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bi-pm:51.1: When her robe is finished and the robe season has ended, if a nun stays apart from her three robes even for a single day, except if the nuns have agreed, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bi-pm:52.1: When her robe is finished and the robe season has ended, if out-of-season robe-cloth is given to a nun, he may receive it if she wishes.
pli-tv-bi-pm:52.2: If she receives it, she should quickly make a robe.
pli-tv-bi-pm:52.3: If there is not enough cloth, but she is expecting more, she should keep it at most one month to make up the lack.
pli-tv-bi-pm:52.4: If she keeps it longer than that, then even if she expects more cloth, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bi-pm:53.1: If a nun asks an unrelated male or female householder for a robe, except on an appropriate occasion, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession. [See essay on cīvara.]
pli-tv-bi-pm:53.2: These are the appropriate occasions: her robes are stolen or her robes are lost.
pli-tv-bi-pm:54.1: If an unrelated male or female householder invites that nun to take many robes, she should accept at most one sarong and one upper robe.
pli-tv-bi-pm:54.2: If she accepts more than that, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bi-pm:55.1: If a male or female householder has set aside a robe fund for an unrelated nun, thinking,
pli-tv-bi-pm:55.2: 'With this robe fund I will buy robe-cloth and give it to nun so-and-so;'
pli-tv-bi-pm:55.3: and if that nun, without first being invited, goes to them and specifies the kind of robe-cloth she wants, saying,
pli-tv-bi-pm:55.4: 'It would be good if you would use this robe fund to buy such-and-such robe-cloth and then give it to me,'
pli-tv-bi-pm:55.5: and she does so because she wants something fine, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bi-pm:56.1: If two male or female householders have set aside separate robe funds for an unrelated nun, thinking,
pli-tv-bi-pm:56.2: 'With these separate robe funds we’ll buy separate robe-cloths and give them to nun so-and-so;'
pli-tv-bi-pm:56.3: and if that nun, without first being invited, goes to them and specifies the kind of robe-cloth she wants, saying,
pli-tv-bi-pm:56.4: 'It would be good if you would put these separate robe funds together to buy such-and-such robe-cloth and then give it to me,'
pli-tv-bi-pm:56.5: and she does so because she wants something fine, she commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bi-pm:57.1: If a king, a king’s employee, a brahmin, or a householder sends a robe fund for a nun by messenger, saying,
pli-tv-bi-pm:57.2: 'Buy robe-cloth with this robe fund and give it to nun so-and-so,'
pli-tv-bi-pm:57.3: and the messenger goes to that nun and says,
pli-tv-bi-pm:57.4: 'Venerable, I have brought a robe fund for you. Please receive it,'
pli-tv-bi-pm:57.6: ‘We don’t receive robe funds, but we do receive allowable robe-cloth at the right time.’
pli-tv-bi-pm:57.8: 'Is there anyone who provides services for you?'
pli-tv-bi-pm:57.9: the nun, if he needs robe-cloth, should point out a monastery worker or a lay follower and say,
